18:36 What you're here for. You're welcome.

The force on the ball is proportional to the pressure (psi * cross-sectional area of ball in square inches gives force in pounds). Acceleration is proportional to force given the constant baseball mass, and v^2 = u^2 + 2as: u is zero so v^2 = 2as hence v is proportional to sqrt(a), hence v is proportional to sqrt(psi). Your graph should rise steeply from the origin and then flatten out as the tank pressure increases.

I'm not sure you delved into the event of the "sprinkle mach fondant" enough. The first instance you can notice it there is after the initial cloud of impact is starting to clear and separate. At that point the baseball had left the container of sprinkles. But if you look back at the footage, the dust kind of clears and those spots in the corner are already there. Some sprinkles got launched so hard and fast from that impact they hit that frame and created enough heat to melt together.

I mean that's a given that that was the event that occurred, but it's amazing that it happened that fast. That is so much energy being imparted to those sprinkles to melt them that much and even to the sprinkles that deformed on the backstop. But you think of how much energy is needed to melt a sprinkle from impact and then launching a few dozen sprinkles from another impact, this thing just gets wilder and wilder.

Also, I think the disappointment you got from the jar of mayo was due to the smell, the mess, and your expectations of the forecasted mess coming true. It's almost like a dad thing. You know there's a potential for a horrendous mess, but you still promised them you'd do "anything". Now you're left with said horrendous mess and you can only blame yourself for being extra-lenient with "the kids" (your patrons) and you can't get mad at them. It's like shooting off bottle rockets (the ones made from soda bottles) with water and a bike pump, fun and safe. Then someone asks you to shoot it off using baking soda and vinegar and now you're covered in vinegary baking soda mess and smell like a whole lot of ugh; except you're smelling like rank mayo on a hot day.

Hey, great video! I do have a question though: I can see on the velocity cam that it's positioned so that the end flags appear exactly in line with where they really fall on the axis perpindicular to the camera's view. This seems like it would allow you to get an accurate measure of velocity over the entire distance by measuring the time the ball takes between flags on camera. However, it is also obvious that parallel lines that are perpindicular to the ball's path do NOT appear parallel on camera due to fore-shortening. Perhaps the effects are simply small enough to be negligible, but wouldn't this fore-shortening make segments closer to the middle of the path appear larger on camera, thus giving you a distorted velocity vs time graph?

Question for you, Destin, if you see this :) I haven't watched it all yet so apologies if I'm asking a dumb, already answered question... When filming from the side, how do you account for the parallax effect of the lens? Only dead in front of the camera are you measuring 100% lateral movement. When the ball leaves the cannon, it is is say 10 degrees from centre of the camera line of sight. Sorry, my terminology isn't great; I'm not a mathematician or an engineer... Or is this a non factor because the same parallax is applied to the distance markers? What I'm trying to say, is that because you're looking at the ball's path at exactly 90 degrees ONLY when it's directly in front of the camera, how do you account for pixels on a 2D screen representing different distances depending on the ball's location in a 3D world?

I hope that makes sense. As I say, I'm not a scientist or mathematician of any sort so I struggle to express what I'm trying to ask or explain. It's a linear scale in the 3D world when the ball leaves the cannon, from a 2D frame of reference because of angles, there's a parallax. I'm guessing the simple answer is that is difference is so small it probably doesn't matter.

I have a brain storm!  I have a wood stove (fairly small size) that must be exhausted horizontally…therefore drafting the smoke/fumes is moot.  I had the idea to use a venturi effect by inserting the 3-inch diameter stainless steel…Hot Exhaust Pipe (HEP) inside a box (even a wood box) of sufficient size to also allow three high speed CFM 5-to-6-inch diameter computer like fans (or any fans for that matter) to be attached to the bottom (or sides) of the box.  The box air pressure would increase but be allowed to escape through a reversed funnel reducing down to about 4 inches in diameter and then expanding via a reversed funnel (attached to the first one) in which there would be created a low pressure just past the joint of the two funnels…. At that location is where the HEP would terminate and (hopefully) create enough low pressure to draw the exhaust/smoke from the HEP and stove. There would also be a separate fresh air feed into the front of the stove for makeup air.  Searching the internet there seems to be nothing out there like this and thought this would be a good DIY project but would like you all to build one and see how the adjustment location of the end of the HEP would need to be placed (perhaps making it someone adjustable) as the best low pressure ‘spot’ must be critical.  How about giving this DIY project a try?  Thanks Gordon

I question whether the drag on the supersonic baseball ever decreases with increasing velocity as you have drawn it.  I've been thinking that this behavior is a common misconception based on drag COEFFICIENT decreasing, but that velocity-squared (V^2) usually dominates and overall drag never (almost never?) decreases with increasing velocity.  I think you could do a good job covering this misconception if it really is one.

There will be a point where drag/friction will severely limit the top end of your baseball. Well, that and the insane amount of pressure you would need to generate. Anyways, you can get a little bit more speed by doing what the Air Force did at the High Speed Test Track at Holloman AFB NM. They were having a problem getting the test vehicle into hypersonic speeds. The air drag would heat the nose to white hot. But, how can you reduce the drag? The solution was a three mile (!) long by 3 foot diameter plastic baggy filled with pure helium. The moment the sled forebody entered the tube, drag was reduced by ~80%. All that thrust that was wasted before was now free to propel the sled. You could tell the moment the sled entered the helium by the sudden jump on the acceleration chart. Looking at the high speed photos, you could see the nose of the sled was white hot and when it entered the helium, it went to a dull cherry red. The end result was the sled achieving hypersonic speeds of 9,000+ fps. The other problem was how do you stop an earthbound body moving at 9,000 fps when your track is only 10 miles long? Mayonaise was not an option, so a 10 foot solid cube of concrete was used instead. A 120 lb. body traveling at 9,000 fps does carry enough energy to vaporize the block.

You could use the helium baggy trick. But, given the shorter distance you use and the flat trajectory, it would be quite possible to use a clear 8 inch or larger stiff plastic tube from the muzzle to the target. Then pull a vacuum on the entire assembly. The tube would have to be strong enough to take the pressure from the initial pressure release. With the ball in a vacuum from the back of the barrel to the end of the tube, you should be able to get a significant boost in speed to the target.

So to pose the question, what would it look like if the mayo was in a vacuum or near vacuum? The only way I can think to test this on earth is build an airtight container several feet in diameter and have a milar covering over a hold you're shooting into. This way the ball goes from a vacuum in the cannon, though air, then into another Vacuum where the mayo is. Major drawback is that the vacuum container probably won't survive more than 1 shot. Just something to think about and possibly test with other things first.

Not sure if the software is doing that calculation accurately, but you might be losing some measurement precision by assuming a 90 deg angle throughout the flight path. The pixel method should calculate the angular velocity and only in the center of the flight path with 90 deg this will translate linearly to proper velocity. Closer to the edges of the camera, there is some cosine-shaped error that you are accumulating that depends on the field of view / focal length of the camera lens used in the high-speed camera.

Once, around 7 years ago, my 14 year old son and I were throwing ping pong balls at each other. He wasn't throwing as hard as I was and I quipped saying "you need a ping-pong ball shooter to even things out". A thought and two weeks later and we had shooter that used two vacuum cleaner motors with makeshift tires fastened to the top of each rotor pin. Similar to a pitching machine in baseball. Putting a ping pong ball close to the oppositely rotating tires grabbed it with great force and shot it out the other side. The ping pong ball shot out insanely fast but we had no way of measuring its velocity.

Fast forward 4 years and as a senior in H.S. my son needed to bring in a working machine to his physics lab. So...in the lab he fired it up and let a ping pong ball loose. It curved, missing the target, and hit the corner of a porcelain sink. The ball was destroyed and the sink had a small missing chip of porcelain and a tiny crack. I guess the class roared at the destruction. To this day I am frustrated that I have no way of measuring the ping pong balls speed without spending many moneys.

It would really be good for everyone if you made an effort to also include Metric units.

Even if only for the sake of making the video more understandable by everyone using the platform on which it's published.

In case you're not aware, there's really good reason why the rest of the planet has standardized to Metric. Studies done to try and measure the impact of using other systems as well like US does have found it's surprisingly costly. E.g 200,000+ unnecessary deaths per year in US hospitals from conversation errors calculating dosages. +10% cost of building a house compared to using only milimeters for measuring due to errors and excess waste. Etc.

Bottom line, any aid or encouragement to further US adaption is going to benefit everyone, most of all young people and future generations in US. It's worth the few minutes it takes to add or learn if you don't know how already. Just ask comments, we'd would be happy to help.

These videos are fun and interesting and you have a great opportunity to set an even better example that's genuinely meaningful.

You need to use the pressure differential between the tank and the barrel as the pressure that the velocity is plotted at, instead of plotting it at just the tank pressure. The pressure gradient between the barrel and the tank is the ONLY thing that is causing the ball to accelerate, so only the magnitude of this differential matters. Thus, a tank pressure of 300 psi and a vacuum of -7.2 psi should give the same velocity as a tank pressure of 307.2 psi and no vacuum.
You could probably get the same information either way if you do the 3D surface plot of tank pressure vs barrel pressure vs velocity, but using the pressure differential will be much easier to interpret.

根据《山海经》的记载，大禹治水一共九年，不但到过美国，还到过欧洲，到过中东、红海、地中海一带。

研究大禹治水，从历史上简直看不出来经过的情况。那时全国的人口，大概比现在的台湾多不了多少。但是他能在九年当中，打开了长江、黄河，把全国的洪水放流到大海去，这可是不容易做到的啊！况且在《山海经》那个传记中，东南亚各国，他都到过的，他究竟怎么去的？当时又没有飞机；据道家讲，他是骑在龙背上，飞到各处去的，这类的神话太多了。又说当他要打开黄河上游那个龙门的时候，只要符咒一画，天上就有个巨灵人下来。那巨灵人按照大禹的指示，手搭到华山这一边，两脚蹲在黄河对岸，不晓得怎么样一推，龙门就打开了。这个过程当然很快，只要几分钟，所以他九年当中，能把全国的大水治好。

我们现在听起来蛮好玩的，究竟是科学？是神话？仔细想想，这个里头有很多的问题。上古连机械都不发达，不要说打开龙门，就是以全国的人力去挖长江的一截，给你三十年也做不到，为什么九年治水就成功了呢？像这些资料，都在中国《道藏》里，要从大禹的传记中找才有。

《山海经》愈看愈神怪，演变出来说到全世界的人类中，有个穿心（贯胸〉国，人生下来，身上有个洞。贵人才有洞，不是贵人没有洞，或者洞也小一点，这个洞是对穿的，贵人吃了饭要走路，下面人拿个杠子，两边一套，两个人就抬走。除了穿心国，还有各色各样的国家，各样人类。现在倒不是我们在搞《山海经》，是外国人在研究，研究过来研究过去才知道，大禹是到过美国的，最近还发表论文等。有个美国同学问我：老师啊！台湾买不买得到《山海经》啊？我说买得到呀！我告诉他地方，他买一部赶紧要研究。

Make like a 1x1 sq meter plywood platform or similar and then drill a one inch hole every cm, and do 4-8 holes per row and then one cm between each row for the whole length of one meter. That's one strip on this platform. Then do another, but this time with 2 cm between, and then one with 3 cm, if you can squeeze it in there as well. Then do another platform with 5 cm between the wholes! The reason for the different spaces, are to find out if the trajectories of the spaghetti shrapnel will differ much between them. As well as, determining if the cascading effect, will change considerably.

You can't measure distance using pixels, at least not how your doing it.  Assuming the camera is in the middle, at the 15ft mark and pointed at 90 degrees to the line of fire, as you go further to the right or left of that center line, each pixel will be a greater distance on the line of fire.  Unless your camera is infinity feet away.  The further away your are, the less off you will be, but like I said, until you make it to infinity, there will be an error.  It's trigonometry.  The 15 foot mark is closer to the camera than the points that are left and right of it.  The further left and right, the further you are from the camera.  The further you are from the camera, the smaller things will be.  So 1 pixel at the ends will be a longer distance than 1 pixel in the middle.

First shot was with a vacuum and was 913 mph.  Second shot was with no vacuum and was 849 mph.  However, you don't have an estimate of the variation for the "with vacuum" shots, so we can't really say if the lower number for the second shot was due to natural variation or due to the lack of a vacuum.  You need to shoot several times with the vacuum to get a feel for how much the speed will vary for repeated shots under fixed conditions.  After we have that estimate of variability, then we can confidently say if 849 is due to the lack of vacuum.

Great video! However, there may be a problem with your setup. You're using pixels to measure the distance, but since you're looking at a long stretch, each pixel does not represent the same distance due to the angle between each pixel and the camera. I doubt it would be enough to seriously alter your results (especially considering that you're measuring at the same spot each run), but you may not be able to rely on the coefficient of drag beyond a few decimal places. Pedantic, I know, but it's something to keep in mind if you do something like this over a very large distance. Thanks for the awesome videos!

A method for constructing 3D surfaces in the field btw for quick visualization - use dowels cut to length for the data point (quick to do with snips) stuck into half inch pattern pegboard.  Two layers of pegboard, small space between, and layer of solid behind to stop dowels falling through.  Pegboard rows and columns are your controlled variables, dowel length is your uncontrolled variable.

Dear Destin,

Thanks for another magnificent video, that mayonnaise massacre was not something I thought would fascinate me. One thing that I know I would love to see is a slow-mo shot down the cannon's barrel, capturing the baseball's lateral and vertical movement as it flies. As the baseball is a knuckle ball (9:47), I wonder how much dip and swerve we would see. Moreover, if you find that there is significant movement in the ball, it would be cool to model it over longer distances because it could help make the cannon more accurate.

I understand that this would require a long lens with almost telescopic depth of field and some trial and error, but I know that you are capable of pushing slow-mo filmography to its limit. This is definitely within your reach and I would love to see a video about it someday.

Keep up the great content!

Sincerely,

Ali

You probably already though of this, but it looks like the monoscopic distortion (especially at the barrel exit) is significant. The amount of distortion along that straight path of flight follows a non-linear curve (perhaps quadratic), but (unless your software accounts for it) your distance-to-pixel software creates a linear relationship between the two. Perhaps the effects are negligible, but my gut reactions says it should be taken into account, especially when that error gets baked into further calculations on drag and squared.

Just one little thing to say about the methodology. Even though the camera is at 90° angle, it is only viable for the middle flag (add in the margin of error i guess). The angle would be quite different for the other flags, right and left.

To be able to draw an exact measurement, you'll need a camera for each flag at a 90° angle, and after synchronization from all footage, note at what time the ball crosses the path of the camera/flag. That would be correct (unless I forget something). Gravity is probably negligible at those distances.

Still, impressive job and thanks all for your amazing work and content.
